sect2.title: Location-Speakers
sect2.para: Beja is a closely related group of language varieties and dialects spoken in the Red Sea coastal and hill regions in Sudan, Eritrea, and Egypt by more than a million individuals. The variety documented here is that of the Arteiga tribe in the vicinity of Port Sudan and Suakin, Sudan. This variety was studied by Richard Hudson (see especially Hudson 1976), and the data has been made conveniently available in a survey article by David Appleyard (Appleyard, 2007a).

biblioset.title: Morphologies of Asian and Africa (2 vols)

sect1.title: beja-arteiga Paradigm Lexemes
sect1.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms
lemma gloss properties
bs bury conjClass=prefix, pos=verb, rootClass=CVC
dbl collect conjClass=prefix, pos=verb, rootClass=CCC
dgy hear conjClass=prefix, pos=verb, rootClass=CCY
k-y be conjClass=suffix, conjType=irregular, pos=verb
lw burn pos=verb, rootClass=CVC
tam eat conjClass=suffix, pos=verb

sect1.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
sect1.para: Arteiga Beja paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

itemizedlist.title: Morphological Type Of Paradigm entry
itemizedlist.para: Some paradigms are categorized by the type of token in the paradigm:

listitem.para: Arteiga Beja makes more PNG distinctions than are found in the Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern

Although Beja has the same property-value features as the rest of Cushitic (viz., sg/pl, p1/p2/p3, m/f), it has a more extensive (and more archaic) set of gender distinctions:
number person gender
sg p1 "⊤"
sg p2 "m"
sg p2 "f"
sg p3 m
sg p3 m
sg p3 f
pl p1 "⊤"
pl p2 "m"
pl p2 "f"
pl p3 "m"
pl p3 "f"
I.e., where gender is distinguished not only in the third-person singular, but also in the third-person plural, and in the second-person singular and plural,.

itemizedlist.title: Noun and Pronoun Properties
itemizedlist.para: Exceptionally some examples of noun plural classes, and of the postposition system which is shared by nouns and pronouns is documented here. Included in the pronominal paradigms are those of the definiteness marker.

listitem.para: defClass: these are the classes of definite parker

itemizedlist.title: Verb Properties
itemizedlist.para: In the Beja verb generally, there is a complex interaction among the categories of polarity (with a marked affirmative-negative asymetry), conjugation class, root class, tense stem class, and tense-aspect-mode marking. The following tables to give a general orientation. For detail, the actual paradigms must be inspected and compared.

For all verb classes, tense-aspect-mode morphology is built on a system of seven stems. For the three root classes of the prefixing verb the stems are differentiated by affixation and internal vowel change; the suffixing conjugation stem remains invariable, but as can be seen from the paradigms themselves, comparable vowel alternations and affix series can be detected in the inflectional suffixes (which are commonly assumed to originate from encliticized stem-changing auxuliaries). Note that in the negative stem forms, even the suffixing conjugation verb receives prefixes. The following is a table of these stem forms (numerotation as in Hudson1976 and Appleyard2007; lexical items as above): Beja tam Stem Classes
StemClass Label prefix-CCC prefix-CCY prefix-CVC suffix
1 pastStem -dbil- -dg- -lw- tam-
2 participleStem dibl- digy- lw- tam-
3 aoristStem -ii-dbil- -dig- -ii-lw- tam-
4 modalStem -ii-dbil- -dag- -ii-lw- tam-
5 presentStem -ee-dbil- -deg- -ee-lw- tam-
6 negStem -dabiil- -dag- -liw- -tam-
7 presentSgStem -danbiil- -dang- -nliiw- tam-

The distribution of these stems among the tense-aspect-mode categories is illustrated in the following table (where the stem-form is illustrated by the prefix-CCC root class verb dbl. Note that in the present affirmative tense, there is a stem distinction between singular persons (with infixed -n-) and plural (with prefixed -ee-).Note further that these are all non-compound tenses, with the exception of the negative past. The very limited and participle-based future tense has forms only for the first person singular and the second person. Arteiga Beja Tense Formation (ordered by tam category)
tam polarity StemClass StemClassLabel stem-form
present-sg aff 7 presentSgStem -danbiil-
present-pl aff 5 presentStem -ee-dbil-
present neg 1 pastStem -dbil-
past aff 1 pastStem -dbil-
past neg 2 participleStem dibl- (plus conjugated aux k_y 'to be')
aorist aff 3 aoristStem -ii-dbil-
future aff 2 participleStem dibl-
imperative aff 1 pastStem -dbil-
imperative neg 6 negStem -dabiil-
jussive aff 4 modalStem -ii-dbil-
optative aff 4 modalStem -ii-dbil-
optative neg 6 negStem -dabiil-
ptcpl-present aff 2 participleStem dibl-
ptcpl-present neg 6 negStem -dabiil-
ptcpl-past aff 2 participleStem dibl-
ptcpl-future aff 2 participleStem dibl-
ptcpl-conjunctive aff 2 participleStem dibl-
ptcpl-conjunctive neg 6 negStem -dabiil-

A better idea of the correlation of tam-stems and tam-categories may be had of the following reordering of the last table: Arteiga Beja Tense Formation (ordered by stem)
StemClass StemClassLabel stem-form polarity tam
1 pastStem -dbil- aff imperative
1 pastStem -dbil- aff past
1 pastStem -dbil- neg present
2 participleStem dibl- aff future
2 participleStem dibl- aff ptcpl-conjunctive
2 participleStem dibl- aff ptcpl-future
2 participleStem dibl- aff ptcpl-past
2 participleStem dibl- aff ptcpl-present
2 participleStem dibl- neg past
3 aoristStem -ii-dbil- aff aorist
4 modalStem -ii-dbil- aff jussive
4 modalStem -ii-dbil- aff optative
5 presentStem -ee-dbil- aff present-pl
6 negStem -dabiil- neg imperative
6 negStem -dabiil- neg optative
6 negStem -dabiil- neg ptcpl-conjunctive
6 negStem -dabiil- neg ptcpl-present
7 presentSgStem -danbiil- aff present-sg

listitem.para: augment: each theme can occur in an augmented (intensive) or simple form. The only form agumentation documented here is vowel lengthening. However root and root-consonant reduplication is also possible.
verbClass: some paradigms are marked for special classes of verb

rootClass: the first three classes are of the prefixing verb, and correspond formally to Semitic strong, final-weak, and bi-consonantal roots. Verbs in the suffixing conjugation have a single, invariant root-class (although there are morphophonemic differences arising from stem structure which are not covered here).

tam: as noted in the above table, these are all non-compounding tenses (with the exceptio of the past negative, which is composed of a participle plus a conjugated form of the prefixing irregular verb k_y 'to be').

aorist: What is here called the aorist is what Reinisch calls “plusquamperfect”,Roper “conditional”,and Hudson “past” (what he calls “preterite” I have here called past). Hudson’s glosses indicate a tense referring variously to a remote or anterior past event,a continuous or on-going past event,or a doubtful event,whilst in Roper the same form seems to be used mainly in the apodosis of unreal conditions. Almkvist’s informants were apparently unfamiliar with such a tense,though he notes that Munzinger had recorded a “plusquamperfekt”

sect1.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
sect1.para:
The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,⊤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].
